 TL:DR This is a visual novel and not a game. You make a few major choices at the climax to drive it to a specific conclusion. The story is short so you can finish within one sitting, that is if you are into reading. If the music annoys you, feel free to mute. If you do not like ramblings, then skip straight to pro and con list below.Don't let the negative comments get you from downloading this free game. It is known that story based "games" are not for everyone. Granted, when I first downloaded this game I was hoping for more then just dialogue and a few choices here and there. I stuck with it, however, and wanted to see where I would end up. I ended up following a story that goes further then just the stoic version of the protagonist which quickly breaks down later. Game critiques do what game critiques do, play for 10-20 minutes and base their critique off that short amount of time. Not trying to bash critiques as they are completing their objective the way they see fit. I on the other hand went through the entire game before making my critique. Pros   About 1-2 hour story, so does not drag on forever (will be continued in further installments like a book in a series).  Major choices at the end of the game, driving the final product.  Limited artwork so you concentrate more on the story (sorry, I come from a generation that cares more for words then             pretty pictures so be forewarned).  New age of openness by being gay within the story without being subjected to fan service art.  Music is astounding, however can become repetitive which leads me to my next pro.  Full set of options including fullscreen, audio control, and having the text auto advance if you do not want to be bothered by clicking. Cons   Limited choice selection, although major decisions towards the end.  Not really a game  Scenes repeat which may be boring for those interested more in art.  Story is a bit shallow at the beginning.  Character development for one of the characters is brought forth too rapidly ruining some of the mystery of the story.As a pun on the story and my conclusion, I let my heart decide my course of action and it led me to my desired ending.

												Well, I downloaded this little gem out of pure curiosity not knowing what to expect. Have to admit, I don't do many Visual Novels. They aren't really "games" in the same since most people think of when hearing the word. If anything, I always think of them as "Interactive Picture Books". Which I don't think if a bad thing, I may not have played many Visual Novels, but I have played enough to where I can say that I know a good one from a bad one. And I've played bad ones. And this... is not one of them. It's a fantastic story actually, that kept me going all the way to the end in one sitting. I didn't stop till the it was over, and it was a very well done V.N. With some very miner grammar mistakes here and there, but to be honest, I don't think there is a single one I've read that didn't have at least a couple grammar errors. They did stick out, but nothing that really pulled me out of the story enough to be much of a bother. The story it's self is far from original, but that's not really a bad thing as long as it's told well. And this one is told very well. Honestly surprised a V.N. that is a free download would be this good. It actually reads more like a science fiction book than the more classic romanticized stories I typically come across when looking at these kind of "games". It's actually pretty refreshing to see one done in this way.The characters in this V.N. are all pretty colorful people. Maybe a bit stereotypical. but honestly there is nothing wrong with using classic stereotype characters, like the tsundere girl who act's superior to everyone, as long as these characters are used in the right way. And I personally believe they are here. Every character, be the a stereotype or not, fits into their respective role perfectly. Anyone who is a fan of Visual Novels, would probably like this one. I'm not even all that big on these kind of things, but I like it quite a lot. One of the best I've read even. And I wish the creators the best of luck in their efforts to make a sequel, cause I do want to know how the story ends with everyone in the story.Having said all that, the main issue I think anyone who already knows what to expect from a V.N. is going to have is the reader's ability to direct the flow of the story. Or rather the lack there of. It's kind of an important part of any V.N. to have reader choices that have a large part in controlling where and how events will happen, be they for better or worse. This story, as much as I like it, is a lot more linear than what I would like it to be. However I did read from the makers of this novel's kick starter that they plan to fix this in the next installment of the story, which I would love to read by the way. Giving readers more power over the protagonists actions and building or breaking relationships between your crew members. With that in mind, I do believe that is a worth while effort to support them in their kick starter, and help bring the next chapter to life. Those are my thoughts on this Novel, and my hopes for the next one.

												Rising Angels: Reborn is a second novel in Rising Angels series. If you wish to know more about the world and backstory you can get the first novel, Rising Angels: The Red Rose, as well as other games kind of set in same universe directly from developer's website: http://www.idhasstudios.com/?page_id=19I played Rising Angels: Reborn before and wrote a small review back then. Republishing it here with small changes.---------------------I applaud to the artist who did character sprites - he or she had to work with the relatively big cast of nine characters and did a marvellous job. Each character identified by distinct silhouette using different body shapes, poses and features like ears, horns and wings. Sprites utilize poses and body language to convey information about the person, like Zuri is almost always shown in positions that imply motion or Stan often drawn covering his mouth with his hand in a gesture subconsciously associated with lying. I think wings were superfluous for character's design - they take too much screen space and people who have wings could be easily recognized without them - but it looks like each race appearances were already defined in earlier novel drawn by another artist and it's too late to change something now.In contrast to character sprites backgrounds look nice and clean, but also grey and unimpressive and there is too few of them, but it's understandable because most of action happens on board of a small spaceship. Game could definitely use more CGs as well; few CGs present are somewhat bland and characters appear noticeably different from their usual sprites. Also, if story takes place on a spaceship, it's almost necessary to show how this ship looks from outside, but I guess nobody in development team could do mechanical design.Music clearly was professional - it sounded like something I could hear before in some games or movie trailers. Perhaps it was licensed from some recording studio. Any sound effects are sadly missing. Adding little sound: footsteps, gunshots, "woosh" of spaceship door would only help immersion.The list of races itself is more what I expect to see in some Star Trek fanfic written by a schoolgirl, not standalone serious work of science fiction: generic fantasy races, angels and demons, furry people - all together in space. Just like in Star Trek, critically important ship personnel are sent with away teams to investigate dangerous planets, apparently unarmed. At least no officers were killed during planetary missions, despite all of them except one wearing red shirts.However, even if Rising Angels series started as mere fanfic, it came a long way and Reborn deserves being distributed through Steam.

												I'm torn about this game.  It has heart.  And the core plot is kind of interesting--there's some decent SF in there.  There's certainly an ambition to explore the characters, what makes them tick and so on.  And I like the art.  The controls worked pretty well although occasionally I wished for a "back" button to look at the previous dialogue again.But if you're expecting anything like realism, expect again.  I just find it incredibly hard to believe in these people as anything resembling military personnel.  Half of them I find hard to believe in as adults capable of dressing themselves.  The main character herself is the least bad, but even her, while I find her emotional arc somewhat affecting, just systematically breaks her original image as someone who supposedly graduated first in her class and is remotely competent.  Not even the whiz she imagines herself to be at the beginning, just borderline capable of seeing things obvious as the nose on her face or taking basic operational security precautions.So for instance (really major spoiler here)We have the doctor, who she suspects of being an enemy spy, who has repeatedly tried to hamper the mission and given signs of knowing things he should not.  In his sickbay is a crewmember who has been poisoned.  He has pretended to have nothing to treat her with, until pressured by people who knew what was in his supplies.  She should have had him arrested for gross dereliction of duty so she could (a) make sure he didn't nobble the crewmember and (b) search his quarters and sickbay for incriminating evidence.  Instead she lets him continue treating this woman and goes off and forgets the whole thing.  What on  earth?!This kind of thing happens time after time, losing the thread or not bothering to follow up on clues or failing to spot or foresee the obvious.  Often because she's busy wallowing in self-pity, something she and some other crewmembers do at the drop of a hat, often just seconds after they've been given an uplifting pep talk and sworn renewed resolve.  And yet it's appropriate for her to be the heroine because despite these flaws she remains the most competent, level-headed person on the ship.  That's because most of the remainder of the crew are unbalanced and self-absorbed to the point of serious mental illness.  It boggles my mind that on a military vessel, over the course of the whole story I don't think anyone except the main character ever just does what they're told without a bunch of back-chat.  Do I recommend this game?  Is there a "maybe" button?  It was kind of fun, and "free" is an awfully attractive price point.  But I constantly wanted to yell at the screen.  And the characterization had possibilities but after laying it on with three or four trowels they seem to have decided that wasn't getting it done and went for the back-hoe.  In the end, I'll recommend it; it's worth more than they're charging.

												I rarely if ever write reviews, but I have played many VNs in my life (both Hentai and Non-H, hehe) so, upon stumbling on one that puts many +$15 visual novels to shame, I simply couldn't let this slip....-Story 10/10''Whom do you trust? And whom you shouldn't trust?'' This is a very mature topic in an even more mature story. So if you expect the choices to answer this question to be as Black and White as the ''Side with the Rebels against the Evil Tyrant, or side with the Evil Tyrant to crush the Rebels.'', then move along; you won't like this VN. But if you like plot full of mystery and doubt, betrayal and friendship, where one single wrong choice could end up dooming everything you care about and you like to feel the jarring tension and drama, then you'll love this work. -Art 7/10OK, this score is a bit viased; for a VN with so many endorphins-releasing situations, moments of sheer shock and fear.... I seriously expected more CGs of them, not just a black screen with the text. I know the most pivotal of them have CGs, but you can count those with one hand and there many, many more events that deserved a CG.As for what Art Style and Quality over all, this VN has better art than many paid VNs; I'd give it a 10 in here.-Sound 10/10The BGMs tend to be quite quiet and inconspicious when nothing of importance is happening, but when something big happens.... Well, the soundtrack kicks in just in the right way (to the point you might find yourself jumping in your seat if you favor headphones). All of the music is beautiful and perdfectly crafted for whatever events are taking place, and that's simply perfect. Love the opening soundtrack, too.-Characters 11/10This review is viased too; I love monster girls in all their shapes (Monster Musume be praised! And Okayado-sensei's previous hentai works too, heheh) so, to have a REAL GOOD STORY, one that's not about silly romantic comedy or pointless fanservice, in a setting with monster girls on it is golden.Going into the specifics, a good Female Protagonist (that isn't oversexualized), a Ditzy Dojikko Dragon with confidence issues, a Tsundere Ojou-sama Kitsune, a Lazy but Lovely Wolf Girl and a Cold and Harsh Elf spelled epicness to me. But, each of the characters is much, much deeper than just their physical traits; each of them feels and acts like a real living being; with virtues and faults, issues and traumas, and with unique and interesting personalities; characters you can relate to. (Such a thing is so rare these days).-Lenght 10/10At first I thought this was too short (beat in on 3 hours, and got the True End in just two tries) and I was about to complain about it. Then, I saw that Kickstarter page with a fully-funded sequel, and all my complains vanished and were replaced by the desire of it being released soon. If it's as epic as this one, I'll get it even if I have to pay.So, to sum up, if you're looking for a fanservice-packed romantic comedy, with lots of bouncing bewbs, panty shots and Gainaxing, then look elsewhere (try NekoPara, which is quite good in all the aforementioned, specially the last two). But, if you are looking for an epic drama filled with emotions and anxiety, then by all means, get this VN.

												Before I start my review, I have to say that I have played a number of Japanese Visual-Novels and have experience in the matter.Rising Angels: Reborn. Is it a good visual novel? Yes.To go into detail, I must say, the amount of detail in the dialogue is better than I expected from a free-to-play visual novel. The characters are believable. You feel that they are alive and that they mean something to you and not just some hollow arch-type character to move you along through the plot. The main story flows fluidly with the characters itself rather than the character-goes-here-for-the-plot type.The music is decent. I mean, for a free-to-play, what do you expect? But, I do have some problems with some scenes in having the wrong kind of soundtrack to play in a heartwarming or first-clenching scenes. Other than that, it was okay.But your main hook on this genre will not be the music, or the graphic (which is obviously CG drawn) or even the endings. Its the character development. You learn their history, their drive to their goal, their will. And you care for them across the story. With the amazing dialogue, I had no problem believing any of the hardships they went through together.In the end, I was left feeling, "Wow, I wasn't expecting this good of an experience." And was satisfied with how the plot ends. I cared for the characters and even for the ones that died. It managed to enter my personal territory and made me feel sad with each hardship they go through. I want them to succeed and I cheered for them. All done without paying a single penny towards the developer. (Which made me feel sour at the end for enjoying such a good experience without paying a single penny)You don't get a massive cliffhanger that makes you want to rip your ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ hair off, but it leaves enough plot to settle for a sequel (which they are working on and is being funded in a kickstarter)All in all, this was a Visual Novel worth of your 2-3 hour of spare time and definitely worth doing all the routes to all the ending. What's even great is it's free! (I wouldn't mind paying this for 5-10$ though)

The race concept Don't let the supposedly cute manga/anime look fool you, the initially light-hearted story becomes actually rather mature and thrilling, because unlike most movies or series (I guess you could compare it a bit with Star Trek or Andromeda), this has multiple endings, allowing twists which can be good, bad or something inbetween and there are several dilemas that have no "right" answer.

												Wow. I mean, as far as visual-novel-esque games go, this one was amazing. I hope this review will satify my entertaining excitement my heart is bursting with right now, for a free game too!First off, story. Amazing, for what it is and how it is delivered. Also, free game, so the content and quality expectations aren't very high. Spoiler-free, you get transfered from a listening post on a space-rock to your first ship where you have a certain mission that you have to accomplish. The story follows a strict space-ship crew exploring / adventuring. The game was actually pretty lengthy but the actual exploring / adventuring that happens is pretty... Eh. 5.5 hrs is a lot for a free game, though. This is the most I can say without spoiling a single thing.Personally, I feel like the story takes pieces from stuff like Star Trek, Mass Effect, etc. The whole crew is of different races, the world that is described in this game piece-by-piece is suprisingly decent for how much you are given in the game itself, not including the codex in the data options menu. From my understanding, it's your classic world that is held together by alliances between major races and an intergalactic "senate", which I think is The Dictators in this game. I may be wrong.Music was amazing. It had the sad heart-felt music. The action-y music. The up-beat "fun" music. It just fit wherever it was played. The tracks are short, so they repeat if you don't read fast enough but they were good enough for me to not care.First off, from what I understand, the romance in this game only has a yuri(girl-on-girl romance in japanese or something)/lesbian romance as I've figured out there's only one romance ending. This game has an obligatory romance theme. Not that it's a bad thing because they do it amazingly well and classy. There's no nudity, so you can only expect excellent art and cute pictures whenever you get them, which are few and far between but still worth it when you get them. Of all the characters(unless I'm missing some hidden options), including the one you CAN romance, have the usual archetypes of usual personalities but they were still done pretty well. You're going to have to insult me here because I can't really explain them but they were all great.There's also a pretty cool "data" or extras section that has a bunch of codex/info you can read. It's amazing for world-building.This is a short review but overall in said and unsaid words, I would definitely recommend this. It's free and it has an amazing story and atmosphere to it. Obviously don't try it if you're not into visual novels or overal story-orientated games. I'd easily give this game an 8/10. It's not perfect and I feel like a legitimate, money-costing game could be made from this. If a free game like this could give at least 5-10 hours and make me feel like every hour was worth it, then yeah. I'm game. It gave me a Mass Effect amosphere but that might just be me.EDIT: For the romance stuff, not sure. I may be wrong but there MIGHT be only one result and it I don't think it's obligatory. I'm playing through / skippinng through the stuff I haven't read yet to figure this one out but I think there's really only one option. One female, two if you count the not-so-much-a-romance-conlcusion

												I would have to say that it’s a charming VN, first and foremost, and would probably deserved some of my money for all the effort and writing put into it. Mind, it isn’t enough to warrant being called a masterpiece, but I would most definitely recommend this to people looking for a good VN.There are five endings, with only the dying ones being particularly bad (and even then, it’s on the grey; it’s a morality issue/reflection). It’s not so hard to get ‘100%’ or what counts for it (completing the gallery since there are no achievements, and probably seeing all the endings) since the choices are obvious but at the same time impactful; they’re not the dreary and mindless ‘pick A for this ending and pick B for this ending’ kind we’re sometimes saddled with and you do have to put some effort into thinking what choice would get you where you want. Mostly, though, there are many choices where it’s hard to say which was the ‘right’ choice - the whole thing deals with differing views of morality and who to trust. In summary, the art is simple (not overtly beautiful, but not ugly; somewhere above passable), the music is agreeable (didn’t really stand out, but I think it did the work justice), the writing is well done (if a tad uncreative at some parts, but it is pretty well-written and gives you much to think about), and the decision points are the exact thing you want out of a Visual Novel (especially with how the decisions reflect on you as a person and your personal take on what should be done, encompassing morality, authority, loyalty, et al.).I can say I enjoyed going through this. I’d give it a solid 7/10 overall, but about an 8/10 where it matters (for the genre).

												At the beginning, I thought this game was an RPG that had a REALLY LONG starting cutscene, but it turned out that it was an interactive storybook. I do not reccommend this game if you don't like reading rather corny dialogues, as it has a LOT of that. also, just to give you a fair heads-up, this book (not game, as it isn't a game, it's just a digital book with a trivial choice here and there) is fairly short and very well-worth the time spent to play it. which is about...oh....maybe two or three hours? it took me about seven, but I click slowly, so....yeah. the soundtrack was mostly boring, but one song was WAY too 'action-packed' for a book like this. the presentation wasn't entirely what I had hoped for, and the characters lacked the level of depth that I am used to.Not to say this book was BAD or anything; I rather enjoyed it. It's just that it seems rather...lacking. still, not bad for free. when I finished reading, it said I had "ending three". implying that there are at least three endings. I rather like multiple ending-stuff, actually....however, I am still yet unsure whether or not I'll hit that 'uninstall button' yet. Playing as a special operative named 'Natalie', I find it odd how you almost never get to see the main protagonist, beyond a facial portrait. Still, I decided to stick with it until the end, because I don't leave things unfinished. As for this book, I am thoroughly unimpressed, even for a "FTR" book. (Free-To-Read.) it wasn't as bad as MOST novels nowadays, but the storytelling was dry, the tense action-parts had no excitement, the mystery-parts had almost no challenge, et cetera. I do not wish to give any spoilers, in case you want to try, then please, be my guest! go ahead. it costs nothing, and was a minor amusement while it lasted. but I'll have slightly lower expectations from part 2.I was expecting an RPG, because everyone was calling it an RPG when they reccommended it to me. what I found instead was a use for a windowed operation to be running while I do resolution tests for my monitor, and RP-chat with friends online in the background. Sadly, I cannot think of any "good points" for this book beyond that the main protagonist, the aforementioned 'Natalie', is slightly visually attractive. but if I wanted 'attractive visuals' and 'eye-pleasing female protagonists', I'd go watch the Vocaloids do their thing.It DID have some nice artwork in it, however....again, not saying much.

												Where to start?I'm making this review having played through the game only once, having gotten the "true end." I'll try to keep spoilers at the very bottom below a warning. Characters: I have to agree with another review long before this. Three characters, at LEAST, wouldn't last long in an actual military situation. It's kind of possible to wave it off as Sol covering for them because they're trustable when it counts, but it still takes a lot of suspension of disbelief. As far as VN games go, it's not outside the acceptable for two of them. But Spoiler doesn't even fit into that. The main character is pretty good, though some of the choices she makes are insane, and that she doesn't figure out a few of the issues is pathetic with how obvious they are. The other characters are good, at least as far as characters go, but they have the same issues of ignoring obvious answers. Speaking of obvious answers with the characters, it would take the antithesis of Sherlock Holmes to fail to figure out who it is early on. Hint: Spoiler. All in all, enjoyable. Art: Hit and miss, really. Most of it is pretty good, some is great, and some is passable. All in the same picture, in one case. Again, it's good overall.Story: Basically, you're isolated to a single ship of a few people on a single mission that spirals out of control due in part to your failure. You go to the surface twice, with one instance possibly resulting in death. Having only played through once, I don't know if the choice in question gets you killed or not. The thing that you're looking for doesn't quite make sense, because it's from a dead civilization, yet Spoiler, despite it Spoiler.Sound: I can't really comment. I played with sound off. Overall, it's a good game with good art, good characters, and a good story. For a free game, I definitely recommend it. It's worth more playthroughs, and I'll definitely being going through it some more. ------Spoilers------The doctor is totally unbelievable. He doesn't know anything with medicine, apparently, he actively tries to prevent the medical treatment of an injured character and nobody bats an eye, and he's so clearly the bad guy that there's no tension. Even his "grand plan" is obvious. Poison the poisened character with a fake antidote and do it all for money. Not to mention that he SOMEHOW has something that can make someone's organs break down just sitting on the ship. Yeah, the smuggling issue sort of covers that, but surely something that bad would be regulated and require the captain to know about it. SOMETHING. Hint: IT'S THE DEMON WHO IS TOTALLY INCOMPETENT YET SOMEHOW IS OF HIGHER RANK THAN THE MAIN CHARACTER. THE ONE WHO IS CLEARLY LOOKS EVIL ON THE START SCREEN.It affects what's used for modern space travel despite the thing it affecting never being said to have other uses (other than ship radios) and only being found in three places throughout the whole galaxy.(Edit) Another spoiler that strains suspension of disbelief. After Stan killed someone, held a gun to Nat's head, tried to kill everyone on the ship, and poisoned Faye, shooting him causes Nat to lose herself. No option to keep the crystal to avoid the government getting it, no option to destroy it even though it wasn't being used in the engine, nothing. Just Nat and Zuri being depressed for the rest of their lives. That's just... too hard to believe. Further, choosing to hand over the crystal to the government says that the crystal was used for the engine even if it wasn't. Not huge, but one of a few small issues.

												I'm going to recommend this day after playing through multiple endings today. First: The characters as just people are fun, and when not likeable are at least enjoyable as antagonists or annoyances. Secondly: They... don't really act very strictly military. Partially, this is explained or at least commented on in-universe. Sol, this ships XO and the protagonist's friend, is constantly frustrated by his backwater no-name ship's crew and their lack of discipline. The ship itself? Small, and as you will learn, poorly equipped and outfitted. Some of the lack of professionalism in the crew can be explained by the fact that, honestly, you're serving on a ship in the dregs.The Art is mostly good. Character sprites, at least, are good. It's a VN, so don't expect them to be too dynamic, but damn the Zuri sprites are expressive and honestly it just made me like her a ton. Music is okay? Honestly the music is the weakest part. It's a VN, so that's not the worst sin, but a great VN has great music. It's not Juniper's Knot. The menu music is like super emo-kid Mayday Parade sounding, which personally I like but I know will make others roll their eyes.The Story? Good. This is pretty decent sci-fi, but do NOT expect hard scifi. And that's fine. Social SF is a thing, it's totally a thing, and this is what it looks like. You are tasked with uncovering a mystery both outside your ship, in the dark of space, and... well, you'll see. The investigation requires you to make a few choices, some of which seem kind of innocent at first. The innocent choices having later ramifcations is actually really interesting and refreshing. The foreshadowing is there, which is nice, but its a bit heavy handed. Overall? It's a decent story that has a lot of potential to be expanded upon in the SEQUEL that will be coming eventually. tl;dr: play it! It's free, it's fun, it's surprisingly good for a free game and a free Visual novel at that. You can make kissu faces at a cute dragon girl, save the universe, shoot people, and be on a crew with a space elf commander! Super fun. Godspeed.

Rising Angels: Reborn is a Visual Novel with a lot of heart and enthusiasm, but the characterization can be weak.Overall, I did like the story, but there was more bickering than useful work being done on this ship, even between friends. 												I recommend this game, but I will freely admit that it will be very hit and miss depending on what kind of games and stories people like. Here's some basic points to touch on (I'm going to skip rating the story itself to prevent spoilers in such a small game; suffice to say that I liked it)Gameplay:Nonexistent. This is the epitome of a visual novel, click to advance text and watch the story unfold and occasionally you will be given a choice of actions to take. Some choices only let you hear varying lines of new dialogue, and others will affect which of the endings you will end up seeing. If you aren't a fan of visual novels, this one isn't inventive enough to change your mind and it will likely be the first thing someone can use as an excuse to avoid this game.Characters:I find the characters varied and they can be fun to interact with. Al and Sol are rather bland, but the hyperactive security officer Zuri and timid engineer Kylie can have some good moments. My only real complaints are that 1) the game isn't really long enough to flesh out any characters other than Kika and/or Zuri and 2) there aren't really enough opportunities presented that let the characters act as meaningful foils to play off of each other.My own personal bias towards the game will certainly be placed in this category. I personally resonated with Natalie's story and personality; not just her "Why does everyone else get the fun jobs when I'm so much better suited than them?" attitude. No, I mean the entire thing, mistakes an harsh self-realizations included.Linguistics:Okay, time to be brutally honest. While this feels like a natively English script rather than a translation like most visual novels are, there are a few typos (particularly later in the story) that can really be a distraction. I've dealt with far worse scripts in my time playing these kinds of games, but there were a few sentences that had me scratching my head trying to figure out what they meant before I realized it was simply a script error. At time's like these, it feels less like the native script I mentioned and more like a good fan-sub that unfortunately didn't have enough time to proofread their later files before hitting deadline of some sort. This doesn't make the game unplayable by any means, but given that I've seen people condemn perfectly good games for far less, I felt I needed to come clean and mention it.Art: The visual presentation of the characters feels distinctly different from the raw anime/manga-inspired designs I've gotten used to, but I can't say that this style is bad. The characters all look pretty nice, and the backgrounds are pleasing to the eye...I still can't understand why anyone would curl their hair into drill shapes though. That will forever be an artistic mystery lost upon my uncultured upbringing I guess.Music:Appropriate for the settings. No individually memorable pieces, but I always felt it was enhancing the mood, not hindering it.Price: The game's free. Look, if you are on the edge about this game to read reviews about it, then get it. It will cost you no money, and it's not some huge, meandering AAA game that takes an ungodly amount of time to finally get into the main plot. I went on a 100% run without a walkthrough or any outside resources and completed everything in (*looks at logged playtime*) six hours. It's not a huge RPG or anything, so by the time you've gone through the first half hour or so, you will likely have met the characters you will be spending the game with and heard the basic premise of the plot, and for a visual novel, characters and story are pretty much everything. So if the game hasn't grabbed you well enough by that time, then drop it, but the least you could do is give it a shot.

												I would have to say that it’s a charming VN, first and foremost, and would probably deserved some of my money for all the effort and writing put into it. Mind, it isn’t enough to warrant being called a masterpiece, but I would most definitely recommend this to people looking for a good VN.There are five endings, with only the dying ones being particularly bad (and even then, it’s on the grey; it’s a morality issue/reflection). It’s not so hard to get ‘100%’ or what counts for it (completing the gallery since there are no achievements, and probably seeing all the endings) since the choices are obvious but at the same time impactful; they’re not the dreary and mindless ‘pick A for this ending and pick B for this ending’ kind we’re sometimes saddled with and you do have to put some effort into thinking what choice would get you where you want. Mostly, though, there are many choices where it’s hard to say which was the ‘right’ choice - the whole thing deals with differing views of morality and who to trust. In summary, the art is simple (not overtly beautiful, but not ugly; somewhere above passable), the music is agreeable (didn’t really stand out, but I think it did the work justice), the writing is well done (if a tad uncreative at some parts, but it is pretty well-written and gives you much to think about), and the decision points are the exact thing you want out of a Visual Novel (especially with how the decisions reflect on you as a person and your personal take on what should be done, encompassing morality, authority, loyalty, et al.).I can say I enjoyed going through this. I’d give it a solid 7/10 overall, but about an 8/10 where it matters (for the genre).

It's a story about who we are, who we want to be, morals and ethics. About balancing emotions with duty, and trusting in others. Politics come into play, and at the end of the day our heroine Natalie has some big decisions to make. As far as decisions go however, there are not that many to make. From my first playthrough I'd estimate I made about 5 choices in 7 hours of game play. I do feel there were more points in the story where user choice would have been appropriate-but obviously that means more writing for the devs in an already fairly lengthy (but enjoyable) visual novel. Even though I didn't have that much control over the story, I was still able to immerse myself and empathize with Natalie and the rest of the characters. While not kinetic, Rising Angels is simply more novel than interactive experience, and that's ok. Oh, I had an experience though, I had a few. I balked at the obnoxiousness of some characters, smirked as Natalie put them in their place, smiled at the sunny dispositions of some, and glowered at the creepiness of others. I experienced frustration and tension, dread and relief. I almost (almost!) got misty eyed at some parts. Overall, the characters had depth and I became invested in them, and the mission. I did have a few qualms with the game, but nothing major. Overall I enjoyed the story and the adventure it took me on, and the characters I met. The few cons I have are lack of choices, a few spelling/grammer errors that made some sentences confusing, and a few points in the story where the writing/situations didn't make sense. The primary example of this for me is  when you have to decide whether or not to smash the crystal you found. When you obtain the crystal, everyone is musing about how durable it must be to survive the spaceship it was on being blown up. And a single touch of it takes out your own crystals. Yet both Sol and Zuri believe that Zuri would be able to smash it with her tail. This idea seems both illogical and dangerous. I can see Zuri suggesting it without thinking, but Sol should know better. Perhaps one could argue that they don't care if they take themselves out (and the rest of the crew) destroying it since they are so close to death anyway, however there is still the issue that they (especially Sol) think it can be so easily broken in the first place, since experience has shown otherwise. There were also some points where I felt like the characters were late to the party, figuring out stuff I had already or finally confirming my suspicions. Also there were some poorly timed humor attempts  (complaining about your video games after discovering your (former) commander dead in a blood pool, REALLY Natalie?) . But no writing is perfect and overall I enjoyed the story and the characters.Rising Angels: Reborn is a refreshing visual novel experience, especially if you are looking for something different than the plethora of school life romance otomes out there. I will definitely be replaying to explore the other paths, collect all the CGs, and learn more about the characters. Apparently it is part of a series so I will be checking into the other games as well. While I do that I suggest giving this one a go!ps: I didn't find out 'till after playing that it's yuri romance only. The romance (at least from my playthrough) is so understated that you could interpret it as close friendship or one sided if you prefer. If you usually don't play girlxgirl romance please still give this a try as it was an amazing story!
